explanation: OS_CHECK_POINTER: This is a macro invoked at the start of the function. Its expansion may contain controlling expressions (if/return/assert) that themselves must be checked for invariance. To judge whether any conditional there violates the MISRA rule you need the macro definition. OS_SymbolLookup_Impl: The function value assigned to return_code is used in the controlling expression if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS). To determine whether that controlling expression can be invariant you must inspect the implementation (or its specification) to see whether it can return different values depending on inputs/state. OS_SymbolLookup_Static: Likewise, staticsym_status is assigned from this function and its value is tested (== OS_SUCCESS). The implementation/specification is required to know if the conditional can vary. OS_SUCCESS: The comparison constants used in both if tests; you need the numeric definition (and any related semantics) to interpret the comparisons and to detect whether macros/functions might always return that value. OS_INVALID_POINTER: Likely used by OS_CHECK_POINTER (or similar pointer-check macros) as a return/error code. Knowing this and other error-code definitions used by the macro helps determine whether the macro's conditionals are invariant or not.  (Only these symbols are required to judge whether the controlling expressions in OS_SymbolLookup are potentially invariant; other callee internals would only be needed if deeper proof of variability is required.)
